title: 110_hr5523
content: The "Internet Gambling Regulation and Tax Enforcement Act of 2008" establishes a license fee on internet gambling operators. This Act also amends the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Internet Gambling Regulation and Tax Enforcement Act of 2008 requires licensed internet gambling operators to pay a 2 percent license fee on all funds deposited into betting accounts each month. The fees collected are deposited into the Treasury's general fund as revenue and are the exclusive obligation of the operator. The Internet gambling license fee is the direct obligation of the operator and cannot be deducted from bet deposits. The term 'Director' is defined in section 5382 of title 31, US Code. The fee may be treated as an excise tax for administrative purposes. "SEC. 6039J. RETURNS OF INTERNET GAMBLING OPERATORS." Every Internet gambling operator subject to section 4491 must provide specified information to the Secretary, maintain appropriate records, and comply with regulations. This includes details such as the operator's information, customers' details, winnings, wagers, losses, tax withheld, and account balances. The information required for tax purposes from Internet gambling operators includes gross winnings, wagers, losses, tax withheld, account balances, deposits, and withdrawals for each customer. Operators must provide this information to the Secretary and furnish a written statement to each customer by January 31 of the following year. The written statement required for tax purposes from Internet gambling operators must be furnished to each customer by January 31 of the following year. The table of sections for internet gambling operators is amended to include a new item. The amendments apply to wagers made after December 31, 2008. The amendment to section 3402(q) extends withholding to net internet gambling winnings over $5,000 in a calendar year. Certain winnings are not exempt, and definitions clarify that net internet gambling winnings are amounts withdrawn from an internet gambling account. The amendment extends withholding to net internet gambling winnings over $5,000 in a calendar year. Net internet gambling winnings are defined as amounts withdrawn from an internet gambling account. Backup withholding now includes net internet gambling winnings as other reportable payments. The amendment extends withholding to net internet gambling winnings over $5,000 in a calendar year, treating them as other reportable payments. Internet gambling operators are considered payors, and individuals placing wagers are payees. Effective December 31, 2008. SEC. 4. WITHHOLDING OF TAX ON NONRESIDENT ALIENS. Tax on Nonresident Alien Individuals is amended to include net Internet gambling income. Certain gambling winnings are exempt from tax, including wagers placed over the Internet. Withholding of tax on nonresident aliens now includes proceeds of net Internet gambling winnings over $5,000 in a calendar year. The amendments made by this section apply to wagers placed with a licensee after December 31, 2008, and include net Internet gambling winnings over $5,000 in any one calendar year. SEC. 5.
